quoteFirst: Last Saturday they called in another physician, Dr. Oliver. On Monday he pronounced her out of danger;
quoteLast: , as Lady Pomfret and Lady Charlotte (Fermor) were sitting by her, the first notice they had of her immediate danger was her sighing and saying, "I feel death come very fast upon me!" She repeated the same words frequently, remained perfectly in her senses and calm, and died about eleven at night.
title: The Wits and Beaux of Society. Volume 2
author: Thomson, A. T., Mrs., 1797-1862; Wharton, Philip, 1834-1860

quoteFirst: Guinness--fell Viljoen as, having stolen past the outposts of Lydenburg, he made to ford the Spekboom river.” The details of the capture were as follows: at
quoteLast: on January 25, 1902, Major Orr with five officers and a hundred and twenty of the other ranks was suddenly ordered to hasten to two drifts, where it was reported that a party of burghers would attempt to cross during the night.[317] Captain Farmer was sent with a detachment to block one of these drifts; near the other Major Orr hid the remainder of his force, posting twenty men in a ruined farmhouse a few hundred yards to his flank.
title: The Campaigns and History of the Royal Irish Regiment, [v. 1,] from 1684 to 1902
author: Gretton, G. le M. (George Le Mesurier), -1934

quoteFirst: “Mingled together, and moving about the area of this oblong square block of buildings, might be seen,
quoteLast: , a crowd of English, Russian, Prussian, Austrian, and other Officers of the Allied armies, together with countless foreigners from all parts of the world. Here, too, might have been seen the present King of Prussia” (the late Emperor William I.
title: A History of the Coldstream Guards, from 1815 to 1895

quoteTime: About seven o’clock in the evening
quoteLast: , weary of the complaints and remonstrances of my people, who continually requested me to stop, and judging beside that we could not be more than five or six wersts from the wood, I assured them that if we did not reach it by nine o’clock, we would go no farther that night; unless when arrived at the wood and the river, they preferred going on, as we should be so near to Ingiga; but that they should be at liberty to do as they pleased.
title: Travels in Kamtschatka, during the years 1787 and 1788, Volume 2

quoteFirst: It was an exceedingly hot blistering day on the river, almost unbearable, and the heat, coupled with the clouds of mosquitoes, impelled the doctor to remark that it was clear to the casual observer that we were in the Arctic regions.
quoteTime: About seven o'clock in the evening
quoteLast: , the thermometer marking 80° Fahrenheit in the shade, we saw "sun-dogs," or parhelia, very plainly marked on either side of the western sun, a phenomenon I had so often observed in the Arctic winter and in Arctic weather elsewhere, as to seem incongruous during such tropical heat.
title:
Along Alaska's Great River
A Popular Account of the Travels of an Alaska Exploring Expedition along the Great Yukon River, from Its Source to Its Mouth, in the British North-West Territory, and in the Territory of Alaska
author: Schwatka, Frederick, 1849-1892

quoteFirst: By this we concluded, that he had been robbed of his property, and that they were not less scrupulous of stealing from one another than from us, on whom they practised every little fraud they could think on, and generally with success; for we no sooner detected them in one, than they found out another.
quoteTime: About seven o’clock in the evening
quoteLast: , the party I had sent into the country returned, after having been over the greatest part of the island.
title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World, Vol. III. Being the First of the Second Voyage
author: Cook, James, 1728-1779; Forster, Georg, 1754-1794

quoteFirst: At first he rallied from the severe shock, and his physicians were hopeful of saving his life, but in the afternoon of September 12, a sudden change for the worse occurred which, it was soon noticed, indicated the approach of dissolution. He remained conscious till
quoteTime: about seven o’clock in the evening
quoteLast: of September 13, and faced death in the same spirit of calmness and submission to the will of God which had characterized his whole career. “Good-bye, all; good-bye. It is God’s way.
title: Famous Assassinations of History from Philip of Macedon, 336 B. C., to Alexander of Servia, A. D. 1903
author: Johnson, Francis, 1837-1908

quoteFirst: My heart kept beating. I was in cruel agitations. King George arrived on the 8th
quoteLast: . The King of Prussia, the queen, and all their suite received him in the court of the palace, the apartments being on the ground floor. So soon as he had saluted the king and queen I was presented to him.

quoteFirst: Again the melodious chant of the _muezzin_--no evening bell can compare with it for solemnity and beauty--and in the neighbouring Mosque, the loudly intoned 'Amin' and 'Allaho Akbar,' far superior to any organ, rang in my ear. The evening gun of camp was represented by the _nakkarah_, or kettle-drum, which sounded
quoteLast: at the southern Gate; and at ten a second drumming warned the paterfamilias that it was time for home, and thieves and lovers, that it was the hour for bastinado. Nightfall was ushered in by the song, the dance, and the marriage festival--here no permission is required for 'native music in the lines'--and muffled figures flitted mysteriously through the dark alleys.
title:
The Life of Captain Sir Richard F. Burton, volume 1 (of 2)
By His Wife, Isabel Burton
author: Burton, Isabel, Lady, 1831-1896

quoteLast: I sent men to inquire about the vessel, and the gentlemen on board informed me that they had come _via_ Port Blair, and would land early next morning.
title: In the Andamans and Nicobars: The Narrative of a Cruise in the Schooner "Terrapin"
author: Kloss, C. Boden (Cecil Boden), 1877-
